omim_title: CONGENITAL DISORDER OF GLYCOSYLATION, TYPE IIt
omim_description: Congenital disorder of glycosylation, type IIt, 618885 (3)
omim_phenotype: Congenital disorder of glycosylation, type IIt
phenotypes: Congenital disorder of glycosylation, type IIt, 618885 (3), Autosomal recessive

lethality_quote: [Duncan et al. (2019) reported 2 brothers, born of consanguineous Pakistani parents, with onset of a severe multisystemic inflammatory disorder soon after birth. Both infants were born prematurely, at 32 and 34 weeks' gestation, due to premature rupture of membranes. The first brother had transient neonatal thrombocytopenia without evidence of infection, and was later noted to have neurodevelopmental delay, poor growth, and thyroid dysfunction around 6 months. At 8 months, he presented with the first of 3 episodes of marked systemic and neuroinflammatory disease manifest as generalized tonic-clonic seizures, lethargy, and developmental regression. He was found to be septic with pneumococcal blood infection and multiorgan dysfunction, including fever, hepatosplenomegaly, increased D-dimers, thrombocytopenia, raised ferritin and LDH, elevated liver enzymes, and acute kidney injury with hypertension and nephrotic range proteinuria. He recovered from this episode and showed mild developmental progress, but had additional similar episodes with seizures, developmental regression, and multisystem involvement without evidence of infection; autoantibody screening was normal. He met the diagnostic criteria for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) and had features of renal thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA). Brain imaging showed progressive diffuse intracranial calcification, white matter disease, and intracranial hemorrhage. He died of infection during hematopoietic stem cell transplantation at age 20 months. His younger brother had similar disease course characterized by abnormal neurodevelopment apparent from early infancy. At about 3 weeks of age, he developed apneic episodes, anemia, coagulation anomalies, and proteinuria associated with brain imaging anomalies, such as intracranial parenchymal calcifications and hemorrhage, abnormal cerebral white matter, and brainstem and cerebellar atrophy. There was no evidence of infection. He continued to have neurologic regression and showed dystonia and EEG abnormalities, consistent with severe neurologic damage. He died at 14 weeks of age]

lethality_quote: [Wornell et al. (2007) described 19 Acadian individuals, including one sib pair, with FRTS5. Most patients came to medical attention because of genu valgum due to hypophosphatemic rickets, with a mean age of presentation of 8.5 years. Average follow-up of patients was 8.4 years. Treatment with alkali and phosphate replacement and vitamin D resulted in improvement of rickets. Hypokalemia was not observed in any patient. Renal biopsy in 1 patient showed mild chronic interstitial fibrosis. Chronic kidney disease developed in half of the patients by age 13 years. Proteinuria was present in almost all patients by age 15 years. Hypertension developed in 7 patients. One patient developed pulmonary interstitial emphysema, and 2 patients developed fatal pulmonary fibrosis following renal transplantation]

lethality_quote: [Isik et al. (2019) reported a 4.5-month-old boy with AMC5. The pregnancy was complicated by decreased fetal movements and polyhydramnios. At birth, he showed severe arthrogryposis with hip dislocation, joint contractures, adducted thumbs, camptodactyly, pes valgus, rocker-bottom feet, and hammertoes. He also had increased muscle tone. Soon after birth, he developed bradycardia necessitating resuscitation and apneic episodes and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. The infant had poor overall growth with microcephaly and dysmorphic features, including prominent occiput, round face with full cheeks, broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, long philtrum, micrognathia, large ears, short neck, kyphoscoliosis, and umbilical and inguinal hernia. He did not have strabismus, but retinal examination showed pale optic discs. At 4 months of age, he had severe hypotonia with inability to lift his head or swallow. He had daily dystonic movements associated with apnea, and he died at 4.5 months of age during one of these episodes.]

phenotype: IMMUNODEFICIENCY 72 WITH AUTOINFLAMMATION AND LYMPHOPROLIFERATION; IMD72
lethality_quote: [Cook et al. (2020) reported 5 patients from 4 unrelated families with IMD72. The patients, who ranged in age from 2.5 to 17 years, had onset of symptoms in the first year of life. They presented with recurrent ear infections, recurrent pneumonia often leading to bronchiectasis, septic arthritis or bacteremia, and skin infections. Organisms included pneumococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas. One patient had HSV-1 encephalitis and molluscum contagiosum, and another had chronic EBV. In addition to immunodeficiency, all patients demonstrated features of an overactive immune system, including asthma, atopy, food allergies, hepatosplenomegaly, and variable lymphadenopathy. Several patients had symptoms consistent with a syndromic lymphoproliferative disease similar to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome or hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. Other severe autoimmune manifestations included immune complex glomerulonephritis with lupus-like features and idiopathic thrombocytopenia purpura after MMR vaccination. Immunologic laboratory studies were somewhat variable among the patients; findings included hyper-IgG (3 patients), poor antibody production (3 patients), increased B cells (3 patients), abnormal levels of memory or activated T cells (4 patients), decreased NK cells with impaired cytotoxicity (3 patients), and defective T-cell activation with impaired cytokine production. Two families had additional affected children who had died]

lethality_quote: [Rodan et al. (2018) described 4 unrelated patients with a similar neurometabolic disorder. Patient 1 was a 7-year-old boy whose prenatal history was significant for polyhydramnios and decreased fetal movement. He was noted to be hypotonic at birth and had global developmental delay. He had behavioral issues including attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and episodic aggression. Dysmorphic features included relative macrocephaly, bilateral ptosis, hypertelorism, deep-set eyes, retrognathia, large ears, bulbous nasal tip, and fifth finger clinodactyly. He had absent eyebrows and sparse hair. An EEG showed electrical status epilepticus during sleep. Brain MRI at 6 years of age showed bilateral germinolytic cysts, peritrigonal white matter volume loss, and a mildly dysmorphic cerebellar vermis. Patient 2 was a 16-year-old girl whose prenatal history was significant for polyhydramnios and macrosomia. She had global developmental delay since birth and behavioral issues including ADHD and aggression. On examination at age 16 years, she had dysmorphic features including macrocephaly, a broad forehead, hypertelorism, deep-set eyes, and blepharophimosis. Scalp and extremity hair was sparse. Brain MRI at 8 years of age showed a thick and short corpus callosum and dilated perivascular spaces. Patient 3 was an 8-year-old boy with global developmental delay since birth. There were no behavioral concerns. Dysmorphic features included high forehead, hypertelorism, ptosis, downslanting palpebral fissures, large ears, and bulbous nasal tip. He had sparse eyebrows and scalp hair as well as hypoplastic nails. Brain MRI at 4 years of age showed periventricular cysts, prominent perivascular spaces and multifocal white matter hyperintensities. Patient 4 was a male who was stillborn at 34 weeks' gestation]

[Early death (in some patients) / Stodberg et al. (2020) reported an 8-year-old girl, born of unrelated Swedish parents, with a syndromic neurodevelopmental disorder... Family history was notable for an older sib with overlapping symptoms who died at 22 days of age]

omim_title: NEURODEVELOPMENTAL DISORDER WITH MICROCEPHALY, IMPAIRED LANGUAGE, AND GAIT ABNORMALITIES
omim_description: Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, impaired language, and gait abnormalities, autosomal recessive, 619091 (3)
omim_phenotype: Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, impaired language, and gait abnormalities, autosomal recessive
phenotype: NEURODEVELOPMENTAL DISORDER WITH MICROCEPHALY, IMPAIRED LANGUAGE, AND GAIT ABNORMALITIES; NEDMILG
phenotypes: Neurodevelopmental disorder with microcephaly, impaired language, and gait abnormalities, autosomal recessive, 619091 (3), Autosomal recessive
lethality_quote: [Manole et al. (2020) reported 24 patients from 13 unrelated families (families 9-21) with a neurodevelopmental disorder associated with biallelic mutations in the NARS1 gene. The patients were ascertained through an international collaborative network of research and diagnostic gene sequencing laboratories. Eight families were consanguineous and of various origins, including Pakistani, Indian, and Libyan. The patients, who ranged in age from 2 to 33 years, presented in infancy with global developmental delay, delayed walking, moderately to severely impaired intellectual development, and poor or absent language development. They had a small head circumference, with most having frank microcephaly (range -2.0 to -8.7 SD). More than half had onset of partial or generalized seizures in the first months or years of life. More variable features included hypotonia, reduced muscle power, broad-based or ataxic gait, spasticity, scoliosis, and clinodactyly. Five patients had a demyelinating or axonal sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy manifest as pes cavus, distal muscle weakness and atrophy, impaired sensation, and decreased or absent reflexes. Brain imaging, when performed, was often normal, although some patients had nonspecific abnormalities, including cerebral atrophy, delayed myelination, thin corpus callosum, and decreased white matter volume. Several patients or their similarly affected sibs died in childhood]

lethality_quote: [Baas et al. (2013) reported 2 unrelated children with MMRCS4 and structural brain anomalies. A boy (patient 1), born of consanguineous parents, developed a B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) at age 9 years. At age 11, he developed a mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland, and 6 months later, he was diagnosed with a T-cell NHL. Brain MRI showed agenesis of the corpus callosum, an interhemispheric cyst, and several periventricular gray matter heterotopias. He also had multiple cafe-au-lait spots. Another patient (patient 3) was a boy who was noted to have dilation of the lateral ventricles on prenatal ultrasound and agenesis of the corpus callosum after birth. He developed an anaplastic astrocytoma of the spinal cord at age 2 years, 10 months. At age 5 years, he developed a T-lymphoblastic lymphoma, and died of sepsis during treatment 9 months later]

(2020) reported 2 sisters, born to consanguineous Lehrerleut Hutterite parents (family A), and an unrelated Turkish male (family B), born to consanguineous Turkish parents, with sulfide:quinone oxidoreductase deficiency and homozygous mutations in the SQOR gene. One sister (patient A.II-3) presented at age 4 years with an episode of fatigue and emesis, and rapid development of encephalopathy with tonic seizures. Laboratory studies showed lactic acidosis and an elevated anion gap. She developed respiratory distress and multiorgan failure, including liver failure. Brain MRI on the fourth day of hospitalization showed diffuse restriction of the caudate, putamen, and globus pallidi, as well as diffusion restriction in the posterior hippocampi, medial left temporal lobe, posterior inferior thalamus, and mamillary bodies. MR spectroscopy showed a large lactate peak and a depressed N-acetylaspartate peak. Muscle and liver biopsy showed normal histology. With supportive care, the multiorgan failure resolved, but she remained comatose and developed neurostorming episodes. She died shortly after discharge from the hospital]

lethality_quote: [Macken et al. (2021) reported 6 girls, ranging in age from 11 to 18 years, from 2 unrelated consanguineous families of Roma Polish (family 1) and Saudi (family 2) origin who had a syndromic neurodevelopmental disorder. The patients presented in infancy with hypotonia and global developmental delay manifest as delayed walking with an unsteady gait (family 1) or inability to walk (family 2). They also had severely impaired intellectual development with poor or absent speech; 1 child was deaf due to a mutation in the GJB2 gene (121011). The sisters in family 1 developed cataracts at 13 and 7 years of age, whereas the patients in family 2 had earlier onset of cataracts. Despite these phenotypic similarities, each family had additional unique features. The sisters in family 1 had metabolic abnormalities with insulin resistance, axillary acanthosis, increased BMI, facial hirsutism, skin striae, and early menarche. These sisters also had dysmorphic features, including upslanting palpebral fissures, high narrow palate, tapering fingers, kyphosis, and foot deformities. One had focal seizures that could be controlled. Family history revealed that 3 cousins of the patients in family 1 had microcephaly and developmental delay and died in early childhood]

lethality_quote: [Courage et al. (2017) reported a family in which a father and his 2 children had isolated complex II deficiency with variable manifestations. The proband was a 60-year-old man with neurologic symptoms since early childhood, when he presented with clumsiness, nystagmus in one eye, cramps in the feet, and speech impediment. At age 15 years, he had worsening ocular paresis, pyramidal signs, and ataxia. He was also found to have cardiomegaly and cardiomyopathy. At age 47, a myocardial biopsy showed increased mitochondria; he was also diagnosed with optic atrophy at this time. The cardiac and neurologic abnormalities were progressive. The patient also had recurrent depression with suicide attempts. Brain imaging was normal. The proband's affected son was a 30-year-old man diagnosed with cardiomyopathy in early childhood. As an adult, he presented with stable cardiomyopathy and developed progressive optic atrophy. Another child of the proband died at 7 months of age due to cardiac insufficiency associated with increased serum lactate and methylglutaconic aciduria; postmortem examination of cardiac muscle showed abnormal mitochondrial accumulation]

phenotype: MICROCEPHALY, EPILEPSY, AND DIABETES SYNDROME 2; MEDS2
phenotypes: Microcephaly, epilepsy, and diabetes syndrome 2, 619278 (3), Autosomal recessive
lethality_quote: [De Franco et al. (2020) reported 6 patients from 5 consanguineous families who had microcephaly, epilepsy, and diabetes syndrome (MEDS). All had severe microcephaly, with a median standard deviation of -6.2; epilepsy diagnosed at ages ranging from 1 to 7 months; and neonatal/early-onset diabetes, with age at diagnosis ranging from 4 weeks to 20 months, that was treated with a full replacement dose of insulin. For all 6 patients, birth weight was low, consistent with reduced insulin secretion in utero. The proband from family II died at the age of 1.3 years, and he had 2 sisters and 2 brothers who were also diagnosed with MEDS and died in infancy]

[Cohen et al. (2019) reported a boy, born of consanguineous Pakistani parents, with IMD14B. He tolerated vaccination in early childhood and was well until age 6 years when he presented with chronic diarrhea associated with colitis and polyarticular arthritis. He later developed features of inflammatory bowel disease. Laboratory studies showed leukocytosis, neutrophilia, monocytosis, and thrombocytosis. Serum IgG and IgA were decreased. Calcium flux in response to anti-CD3 crosslinking on patient T cells was decreased, although T-cell proliferative response was normal. The patient died at age 14 years of severe pneumonia and sepsis. Family history revealed a similarly affected brother who died of sepsis at 6 months of age]

The patients, who were ascertained through the GeneMatcher program, were of various ethic origins, including Algerian, Turkish, Pakistani, Kuwaiti, Hispanic, Finnish, and European. There were 13 pediatric patients, ranging from 10 months to 13 years of age, and 3 adults ranging from 26 to 42 years of age. Two sibs from family 3 died in childhood, and 1 affected sib in family 10 died in infancy; this latter patient also had a homozygous mutation in the COG6 gene (606977) and was excluded from the overall clinical analys]

lethality_quote: [Steichen-Gersdorf et al. (2008) reported a female infant with mesomelic dysplasia characterized by bilateral fibular agenesis and short, dysplastic, triangulated tibiae. The femurs were of normal size. The forearms were slightly short, and the radial heads were subluxed. The feet were in a marked equinovalgus position with postaxial reduction on the left and abnormally spaced toes on the right. Head MRI demonstrated cortical and subcortical brain atrophy and dilatation of the ventricular system. The infant developed apneic spells and myoclonic jerks, and she died at age 4 months following a prolonged hypoxic episode]

[Chai et al. (2021) reported 17 patients from 9 unrelated families with PCH14. The patients, who ranged from 2 months to 13 years of age, were ascertained through exome sequencing; several were identified through the GeneMatcher program. Five families were consanguineous, of Egyptian, Pakistani, or Mexican descent. The patients presented at birth with severe microcephaly (-2 to -6 SD), which progressed postnatally (-4 to -8 SD). Most showed essentially no developmental progress, with absent motor skills, no language, severe intellectual disability, and no social skills. Four patients died between 2 and 8 months of age]
[Death in the first days or weeks of life]

[Patients may die in infancy or early childhood of multiple organ failure / Gauthier et al. (2015) reported an Algerian boy who had megacystis and severe oligohydramnios observed on prenatal ultrasound. A classic prune belly phenotype (see 100100) was noted at birth, and he was anuric; ultrasound confirmed megacystis with normal wall thickness. He also had severe lung hypoplasia requiring assisted ventilation. The infant never passed meconium, and at 3 weeks, transit studies showed lack of opacification of the bowel distal to the duodenum; barium enema showed filiform opacification of the distal colon with no opacification of the cecum, consistent with microcolon. Echocardiogram was normal, and the ductus arteriosus closed spontaneously. The infant died following hemodynamic deterioration and multiorgan failure]

[Hereditary angioedema-4 (HAE4) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by episodic subcutaneous or submucosal edema with onset usually in adulthood. Swelling most commonly involves the face and tongue, sometimes resulting in occlusion of the airway, which can cause death / Bork et al. (2018) reported 18 affected individuals from 4 unrelated multigenerational families (families A-D) with hereditary angioedema with normal C1INH levels... Two women died of asphyxiation due to tongue swelling with upper airway obstruction at ages 36 and 47 years, respectively]

[Ganapathi et al. (2020) reported 6 patients from 3 unrelated families, from Germany, Colombia, and Spain, who presented with severe neonatal CMD within the first day to 2.5 months of life. Echocardiography showed dilated right atria and ventricles, progressing to biventricular dilation with reduced systolic function reflected in markedly low ejection fractions. Valvular insufficiency was present in 4 patients, involving the tricuspid and mitral valves. None of the children exhibited hypotonia. Of the 6 patients, 4 experienced cardiac decompensation and died of cardiogenic shock by 2 months of age; the 2 surviving patients underwent cardiac transplantation at 5 months of age and were alive at 9 years and 10 years, respectively]

All 12 patients had developmental delay, 9 of 10 patients had secondary microcephaly, 7 of 9 patients had dysgenesis of the corpus callosum, 6 of 7 patients had CNS hypomyelination, 7 of 7 patients had cerebral atrophy, and 11 of 11 patients had seizures. Immune anomalies included recurrent fevers in 8 patients, inflammatory arthritis in 3, septic arthritis in 2, aseptic osteomyelitis in 2, and hypochromic microcytic anemia in 4. Other features included hypotonia in 9 patients, muscle wasting in 8, abdominal distention in 4, spasticity in 4, and hepatomegaly in 2. Ten of 12 patients died between the ages of 9 and 32 months, and the 2 living patients were in critical condition]

lethality_quote: [Yu et al. (2021) reported 5 Chinese patients, included 2 sisters, with OPDM3. The mean age at onset was 23.8 years (range 18 to 31). Four patients presented with distal leg weakness and 1 with diplopia and exotropia. The disease was slowly progressive and all patients eventually developed ptosis, facial and bulbar muscle weakness, and distal limb muscle weakness and atrophy with steppage gait. External ophthalmoplegia was also observed. Reflexes were decreased, but sensation was normal. Two patients died of respiratory events]

lethality_quote: [Jones et al. (2019) studied an Iranian family (family 1) in which 2 children died with CMD. The proband (IV-3) had severe left ventricular (LV) dilation with rapidly declining systolic function as an infant; cardiac imaging at 20 months of age confirmed the diagnosis of CMD. By 4.5 years of age, his LV systolic function was severely depressed with medically refractory heart failure, and electrocardiograms showed prolongation of the PR interval, conduction delay, and T-wave abnormalities. He died at age 5 while awaiting transplant. An older brother (IV-2) who died at 37 days of age had presented with sudden fever, poor feeding, jaundice, and hypotonia as a neonate and exhibited cardiomegaly and clinical features consistent with cardiomyopathy. The first-cousin parents also had a pregnancy that ended in spontaneous abortion at 8 weeks (IV-1), and a 3-month old healthy boy (IV-4). The authors studied another consanguineous Iranian family (family 2) in which 2 brothers died at ages 6 months and 2.5 years, respectively, of cardiac arrest. The older brother (V-1) presented with fever, restlessness, and poor feeding at age 6 months, and his clinical status declined until in-hospital cardiac arrest 3 days later. The proband (V-2) was diagnosed prenatally with Ebstein anomaly, and did well until 2 years of age, when he underwent tricuspid valve annuloplasty and atrial septal defect closure. Postoperatively he had episodes of respiratory distress and developed generalized edema and progressive ventricular failure, and died of cardiac arrest at 2.5 years of age]

lethality_quote: [Ucuncu et al. (2020) reported 8 children from 6 unrelated families with PCH16. The patients, who ranged in age from 18 months to 12 years, presented in the perinatal period with axial hypotonia, distal hypertonia, and spastic tetraplegia, often with extrapyramidal signs and progressive microcephaly (down to -5 SD). Psychomotor development was essentially absent: none of the patients learned to walk or talk, and they had poor social skills. Ophthalmologic findings included nystagmus, abnormal ocular movement, ptosis, and cataracts. Four had optic atrophy and 1 was blind. All but 1 patient had seizures, with onset between 1 day and 7 years of age. Brain imaging showed cerebellar hypoplasia, pontine atrophy, enlarged ventricles, atrophy of the cerebral cortex, thin corpus callosum, hypoplasia of the basal ganglia and thalami, and nonspecific white matter abnormalities. Other features included dysphagia, muscle wasting, joint stiffness, scoliosis, and mild nonspecific facial features, including micrognathia, prominent nose, and low-set ears. Four of the patients (including 2 sibs of probands) died in childhood]
